As a cyclist, a cycling fan and an Australian this photo fills me to overflowing with feelings of reverence. It was taken a couple of hundred metres from the finish line of this year’s Tour de France stage 4 and I can’t stop looking at it.

Cadel won the stage by a few centimetres by delivering a sustained attack so vicious that neither Alberto Contador, undisputedly the best climber in the world, nor Philippe Gilbert, a man who just months ago swept the Ardennes classics by destroying the rest of the field on uphill finishes exactly like this one, could come around him.

Those faces belong to two of the most dominant men, not only in cycling, but in this specific kind of finish and they are in pain. Not once this year in any of Gilbert’s destructive Ardennes wins or throughout Contador’s Giro dominance did they look like that. Cadel, an Australian, is on the front, determination contorting his face and body, forcing the best to turn themselves inside out for at most, a second place.

It is glorious.

§ Jul 14th, 2011

I saw a Reddit thread about a month ago asking for inexpensive ways to improve your quality of life. One of the suggestions was to sleep on clean sheets more often. I’ve been doing this and so far it’s working out well.

§ Jul 11th, 2011

Fairfax creating audiences in post-classified era

Fairfax creating audiences in post-classified era

Fairfax CEO Greg Hywood doing nothing but repeating buzz words that neither he, nor anyone else understands. It’s mind boggling the extent to which Hywood doesn’t get it. He calls Fairfax’s iPad app “our iPad”, “there’s been 100,000 downloads of our iPad”. And I like this quote:

If you look at the old business, the old business didn’t really need the journalism.

Now there’s an imperative to produce quality journalism these media companies are really struggling.

§ Jun 27th, 2011

There are three small things that make Twitterrific for Mac my choice over the official Twitter for Mac:

  1. Twitterrific does not automatically shorten every URL I post regardless of length. I want people to know what I’m linking to.
  2. Twitterrific inserts the URL of an uploaded image into the tweet body rather than as an invisible “attachment”. I want to choose where my image URL goes.
  3. Twitterrific has an option for turning off the dock icon.

That is all.

People who can code in the world of technology companies are a dime a dozen and get no respect. People who can code in biology, medicine, government, sociology, physics, history, and mathematics are respected and can do amazing things to advance those disciplines.

Zed A. Shaw as part of more wise words about the art, pursuit and profession of programming. This is something I think about a lot.

Via Tim Riley.

§ Jun 20th, 2011

Not far from where I used to live there was a large area set aside for a cemetery but it was developed into a golf course instead. It would have been more useful to make it a cemetery.

A commenter on this story about running out of grave sites.

I think a golf course is a pretty inefficient and indulgent use of land but to suggest that using the land to store slowly decomposing bodies at regular intervals is better boggles my mind.

§ Jun 13th, 2011

Andreas Klier, Garmin Cervelo hardman, (spoken in a thick german accent, his face covered in dirt) immediately after his team mate, Johan Van Summeren, won the 2011 Paris-Roubaix in a solo breakaway.

§ Jun 5th, 2011

In the past decade or so, researchers have produced a significant body of research measuring the dreadfulness of a long commute. People with long transit times suffer from disproportionate pain, stress, obesity, and dissatisfaction. The joy of living in a big, exurban house, or that extra income leftover from your cheap rent? It is almost certainly not worth it.

Slate states the obvious about the shittiness of long commutes in only 1000 words.

This is why every dollar (of the many) I spend on my apartment, a ~5 minute bike ride from work, is money well spent. Each day I bypass gridlocked traffic on Coronation Drive while cruising along the riverside bikeway. What good is your big house, big backyard or the extra money* in your pocket when so much of the time you could be spending enjoying those things is instead spent in traffic?

Ridiculous beyond belief is the phenomenon of purchasing a luxury car with the money you save by living in the suburbs so the two hours you have to spend in a car each day are more enjoyable. A supreme example of solving the wrong problem.

* When you remove the cost of car ownership (insurance, registration, maintenance), tolls, fuel and parking the perceived increased cost of living is probably false.

Via indefensible.

§ May 26th, 2011

Must Have Good Written and Verbal Communication Skills

I always found it a bit strange that such a thing would be an explicit criteria on every advertised job vacancy. That was before I entered the workforce. Every day I’m further astonished by people’s inability to not just articulate themselves but string a sentence together that makes any sense at all. Combined with a complete lack of brevity I spend so much time either deciphering or slogging through something that can be said with 1/10th the words.

§ May 24th, 2011

The Truly Silent Phone

I don’t like the concept of phones. It shouldn’t be socially acceptable to interrupt anyone at any time with a demand for their complete attention. That said, situations exist where information is important enough to warrant interruption.

To partly deal with it I rarely had my phone set to anything but silent. In reality “silent” mode with vibration on is actually quite loud and jarring, much more jarring than many ringtones and especially if your phone is sitting on a hard surface. Even in a pocket I find the vibration more of a shock than a vibration-less ringtone.

It’s only recently that I identified anxiety attached my ringing and vibrating phone and the attention it demanded. So I decided that as well as permanent silent mode I’d turn off vibrate and I haven’t looked back, it’s a joy.

If my phone is in view the most notification I get of a call or text is a lit up screen. Much less distracting and more easily ignored than a loud ring or vibrate. If it’s not in view I get no notification at all. Even when in view I get zero notification of new email, an added bonus.

Sure I miss a lot of calls but in a couple of months it’s never mattered, people leave a message and can wait until I next check my phone and I’m free to call. If I’m expecting a call and my phone isn’t within peripheral vision I’ll temporarily turn off silent mode.

It’s a simple change and it may sound dramatic but it feels liberating.

Yet another calendar application which doesn’t address my and Marco’s biggest issue. Fantastical is certainly a nice supplement to iCal but it’s a shame that it’s a menu bar app (which I don’t like in general) and its scope is so limited.

Frank Strack again from his post on the death of Wouter Weylandt saying something that has been particularly relevant to me this year.

§ May 15th, 2011

It is said, however, that the great peaks can’t be reached without crossing through deep valleys. Tragically, we were reminded today that our sport is one of great peaks and deep, deep valleys.

Frank Strack in a stirring memoriam to Wouter Weylandt’s death today in stage 3 of the Giro d’Italia. I would have said that words cannot describe the tragedy of a 26-year-old athlete with an unborn child losing his life this way but Frank’s come close.

Apparently there are videos of the crash but like many of the commentators, I have no desire to see it. An incredibly sad day.

Petrol

It’s already too expensive for me to personally justify owning a car and it’s only going to get more and more expensive. Most seem to treat driving like a God-given right and choose to complain about the price rather than do something about it. I’m interested in how expensive it has to get before people start questioning its viability.

§ May 3rd, 2011

The ‘Book’ is Dead

The “Book” is Dead

Mark Pilgram on David Flanagan having to get a salaried job after 15 years living on book sale royalties and the problem of piracy.

I couldn’t agree more with the comments Pilgrim quotes. So few people have an inherent desire to pirate and it’s an accessible option to even less. iTunes “beat” piracy by being better. iTunes is easier, faster and more reliable, it’s simply a more desirable option even to those with the technical acumen to pirate content. With the “bonus” of being the ethical option.

As commenter Peter points out:

I have been an OReilly Safari subscriber for several years. I can recommend this to every developer out there. … Yet, must admit it still pains me that for ~$500/year we as honest subscribers can not get the same convenience (offline access, unencumbered PDF’s) as people who just download a pirated PDF library for free.

Piracy doesn’t “win” for books because it’s free but because it’s better.

§ May 1st, 2011

Here’s a niche thing I made to scratch my own cycling itch: Frugal Rouleur.

I love working on these projects where I get to do everything myself. For this I created a REST API to interface with the online stores, wrote JavaScript that calls the API and designed the front end using my current favourite tools: Sinatra, HAML, SASS and Heroku for hosting.

§ Apr 26th, 2011

The Coolist did a feature on the Washington Metro focusing on the beautiful consistent architecture of its stations. The Paris Metro and NYC subway included, the Washington Metro is by far the best railway system I’ve ridden. As well as their beautiful aesthetic design I always found the stations extremely easy to navigate which is rarely the case for these complex, one of a kind systems.
